open_questions.title: C++
open_questions.description: What is C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: C++ is a general-purpose programming language that is an extension of the C programming language. It supports object-oriented, procedural, and generic programming paradigms and is widely used for system development, game development, and more.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between C and C++
open_questions.description: What is the difference between C and C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between C and C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: C++ is an extension of C with added features like classes and objects for object-oriented programming. C is a procedural language, while C++ supports both procedural and object-oriented programming.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: An object in C++
open_questions.description: What is an object in C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is an object in C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: An object in C++ is an instance of a class, which is a blueprint for creating objects. Objects encapsulate data (attributes) and behavior (methods) into a single unit.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: A class in C++ is a user-defined data type that defines the structure and behavior of objects. It serves as a blueprint for creating objects with shared characteristics and behavior.

open_questions.title: Constructors and destructors in C++
open_questions.description: What are constructors and destructors in C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are constructors and destructors in C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Constructors are special member functions in C++ that are called when an object is created. Destructors are also special member functions that are called when an object is destroyed. Constructors initialize object attributes, while destructors clean up resources.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: this keyword
open_questions.description: What is the this pointer in C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the this pointer in C++?" Requirements: - `this` depends on call-site (how the function is invoked) - Method call vs plain function call - Arrow functions capture lexical `this` - `bind`/`call`/`apply` can set `this` Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: this depends on call-site (how the function is invoked); Method call vs plain function call; Arrow functions capture lexical this; bind/call/apply can set this. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The this pointer is a pointer that points to the current instance of an object. It is used to access object members within class methods when there is a naming conflict with local variables.
keyPoints: `this` depends on call-site (how the function is invoked)
Method call vs plain function call
Arrow functions capture lexical `this`
`bind`/`call`/`apply` can set `this`

open_questions.title: The differences between pass-by-value, pass-by-reference, and
open_questions.description: Explain the differences between pass-by-value, pass-by-reference, and pass-by-pointer in function parameters.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the differences between pass-by-value, pass-by-reference, and pass-by-pointer in function parameters.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Pass-by-value makes a copy of the argument and operates on the copy. Pass-by-reference uses references to the original object, allowing modifications to the original. Pass-by-pointer uses pointers to the original object, similar to pass-by-reference.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Discuss the differences between shallow copy
open_questions.description: Discuss the differences between shallow copy and deep copy when copying objects in a programming language.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Discuss the differences between shallow copy and deep copy when copying objects in a programming language.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Shallow copy creates a new object that is a copy of the original object, but it does not recursively duplicate objects contained within the original object. Changes made to nested objects in the copy affect the original. Deep copy creates a new object and recursively duplicates all objects contained within the original object, ensuring that changes to nested objects in the copy do not affect the original.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Operator overloading in C++
open_questions.description: What is operator overloading in C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is operator overloading in C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Operator overloading allows you to define new behaviors for existing operators when used with user-defined data types (classes). For example, you can overload the + operator to add two custom objects. class MyString { public: MyString operator+(const MyString& other) { MyString result = *this; result += other; return result; } };
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The differences between stack and heap
open_questions.description: Describe the differences between stack and heap memory allocation in a programming language.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "Describe the differences between stack and heap memory allocation in a programming language.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Stack memory is used for function call management, local variables, and is managed automatically. It has limited and fixed size. Heap memory is used for dynamic memory allocation, and you must manage it manually. It has a larger but variable size.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Virtual functions in C++

Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Virtual functions are functions declared in a base class with the virtual keyword. They allow dynamic binding, enabling the selection of the appropriate function to call at runtime based on the object's actual type in a hierarchy of derived classes.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: RAII (Resource Acquisition Is Initialization) in
open_questions.description: Explain RAII (Resource Acquisition Is Initialization) in C++.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain RAII (Resource Acquisition Is Initialization) in C++.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: RAII is a C++ programming idiom where resource management (e.g., memory allocation, file handling) is tied to the lifespan of objects. Resources are acquired in the constructor and released in the destructor of objects, ensuring proper cleanup.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The role of the mutable keyword
open_questions.description: What is the role of the mutable keyword in C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the role of the mutable keyword in C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The mutable keyword is used to indicate that a member variable of a class can be modified even within a const-qualified member function. It allows for logical constness while enabling changes to specific data members. int x = 5; auto lambda = [x]() mutable { x++; }; lambda(); // x is now 6
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The Rule of Three in C++
open_questions.description: Explain the Rule of Three in C++ and why it's important.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the Rule of Three in C++ and why it's important.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Rule of Three states that if a class defines a custom destructor, copy constructor, or copy assignment operator, it should define all three. This ensures proper memory management and prevents issues like resource leaks or double deletion in custom classes.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name hiding in C++
open_questions.description: What is name hiding in C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is name hiding in C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Name hiding occurs when a derived class declares a member with the same name as a member in the base class. The derived class's member hides the base class's member in the scope of the derived class. To access the base class's member, you can use the scope resolution operator (::).
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Function scope vs block scope; var vs let/const behavior. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: const is used to indicate that a variable, function parameter, or member function does not modify the data it refers to. It's used for creating constant values, preventing unintended modifications, and enabling compiler optimizations.
keyPoints: Function scope vs block scope
`var` vs `let`/`const` behavior

open_questions.title: The differences between the new and

open_questions.title: What the Rule of Five is
open_questions.description: Explain what the Rule of Five is in C++11 and later standards.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain what the Rule of Five is in C++11 and later standards.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Rule of Five consists of five special member functions that should be defined when a class deals with resource management: Destructor: Cleans up resources (e.g., memory) when an object is destroyed. Copy Constructor: Creates a deep copy of an object when copied. Copy Assignment Operator: Copies the contents of one object into another. Move Constructor: Transfers ownership of resources from one object to another. Move Assignment Operator: Transfers ownership of resources during assignment.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: The C++ Standard Library is a collection of pre-defined classes, functions, and templates that provide commonly used data structures and algorithms. Common containers include std::vector, std::map, std::set, and std::queue. Common algorithms include std::sort, std::find, std::for_each, and std::accumulate.

open_questions.title: The copy constructor, and when is
open_questions.description: What is the copy constructor, and when is it called?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the copy constructor, and when is it called?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The copy constructor is a special member function in C++ that is called when an object is copied. It creates a new object that is a copy of an existing object. It's automatically called in various situations, such as when passing objects by value, returning objects by value, or initializing new objects with existing ones.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words

open_questions.title: An abstract class in C++? How
open_questions.description: What is an abstract class in C++? How does it differ from an interface?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is an abstract class in C++? How does it differ from an interface?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: An abstract class in C++ is a class that cannot be instantiated and often contains one or more pure virtual functions. Derived classes must implement these functions. It serves as a base class for other classes. An interface in C++ is typically implemented using abstract classes with pure virtual functions. However, an interface only defines a contract (method signatures) that derived classes must adhere to. An abstract class can have some concrete implementation in addition to pure virtual functions.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The const_cast operator is used to add or remove the const qualifier from a pointer or reference. It's often used when you need to work with functions that take non-const pointers or when you need to modify data that was originally declared as const.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of the C++ Standard
open_questions.description: Explain the purpose of the C++ Standard Library containers std::vector, std::list, and std::map.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the purpose of the C++ Standard Library containers std::vector, std::list, and std::map.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: std::vector: A dynamic array that provides fast access to elements by index. It's suitable for scenarios where elements are frequently added or removed at the end. std::list: A doubly-linked list that allows efficient insertions and deletions at any position but has slower random access compared to vectors. std::map: A key-value associative container that allows efficient lookups by key. It's implemented as a binary search tree.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: SFINAE (Substitution Failure Is Not An
open_questions.description: What is SFINAE (Substitution Failure Is Not An Error) in C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is SFINAE (Substitution Failure Is Not An Error) in C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: SFINAE is a principle in C++ template metaprogramming where certain template instantiations are not considered errors during compilation but rather lead to template specialization. It's often used to enable or disable certain template instantiations based on the presence or absence of specific member functions or types.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The use of std::move in C++
open_questions.description: What is the use of std::move in C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the use of std::move in C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: std::move is used to cast an object to an rvalue reference, indicating that the object can be moved from rather than copied. It's typically used in move semantics to efficiently transfer resources (e.g., memory ownership) from one object to another, reducing unnecessary copying. std::vector<int> source = {1, 2, 3}; std::vector<int> destination = std::move(source); // Move contents of source to destination
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of the C++ Standard
open_questions.description: Explain the purpose of the C++ Standard Library algorithms provided by the <algorithm> header.?

referenceAnswers.text: The <algorithm> header provides a set of common algorithms for working with sequences, such as arrays, vectors, and other containers. These algorithms include sorting, searching, and manipulation functions that can be applied to a wide range of container types.

Give a small example

open_questions.title: An inline function in C++? Why
open_questions.description: What is an inline function in C++? Why is it used?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is an inline function in C++? Why is it used?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: An inline function is a function that is expanded by the compiler at the call site, rather than being invoked through a regular function call. It's used to reduce function call overhead, especially for small and frequently called functions. It's typically implemented using the inline keyword.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Type erasure is a technique used to abstract the specific type of an object or value, allowing it to be treated uniformly, regardless of its actual type. It's often used to implement polymorphism without exposing the underlying types.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between a reference and
open_questions.description: What is the difference between a reference and a pointer in C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between a reference and a pointer in C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A reference is an alias or an alternative name for an existing object. It cannot be reseated to refer to a different object after initialization and doesn't require dereferencing. A pointer is a variable that stores the memory address of an object. It can be reseated to point to different objects and requires explicit dereferencing using * operator.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of the decltype keyword

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The decltype keyword is used to deduce the type of an expression or variable at compile-time. It can be helpful when you want to declare a variable with the same type as another expression, especially in generic programming and template metaprogramming.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Function overloading in C++
open_questions.description: What is function overloading in C++?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is function overloading in C++?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Function overloading is a feature that allows multiple functions with the same name but different parameter lists to be defined within the same scope. The appropriate function to call is determined based on the number or types of arguments provided. int add(int a, int b) { return a + b; } double add(double a, double b) { return a + b; }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of the std::mutex class
open_questions.description: Explain the purpose of the std::mutex class in C++.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the purpose of the std::mutex class in C++.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: std::mutex is part of the C++ Standard Library and provides a mechanism for achieving mutual exclusion, allowing multiple threads to synchronize access to shared resources. It's commonly used to protect critical sections of code, preventing multiple threads from simultaneously modifying shared data, which can lead to data corruption or race conditions.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: CRTP (Curiously Recurring Template Pattern) in
open_questions.description: What is CRTP (Curiously Recurring Template Pattern) in C++?

referenceAnswers.text: CRTP is a C++ programming pattern where a derived class inherits from a base class template that is parameterized by the derived class itself. It is used to achieve static polymorphism and code reuse. template <typename Derived> struct Base { void foo() { static_cast<Derived*>(this)->implementation();

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: What the Pimpl idiom (Pointer to
open_questions.description: Explain what the Pimpl idiom (Pointer to Implementation) is and why it's used in C++.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain what the Pimpl idiom (Pointer to Implementation) is and why it's used in C++.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Pimpl idiom is a design pattern in C++ where the implementation details of a class are hidden behind a pointer (or smart pointer). This is done to achieve better encapsulation and separation between the public interface and private implementation details. It can also reduce compile-time dependencies and improve compilation times when implementation details change.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Smart pointers in C++? Explain the
open_questions.description: What are smart pointers in C++? Explain the differences between std::unique_ptr and std::shared_ptr.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are smart pointers in C++? Explain the differences between std::unique_ptr and std::shared_ptr.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Smart pointers are C++ objects that manage dynamic memory automatically, helping to avoid memory leaks. std::unique_ptr is used when you want a single owner for the resource. It ensures that the resource is deleted when the unique_ptr goes out of scope. std::shared_ptr allows multiple pointers to share ownership of a resource, and the resource is deleted when the last shared_ptr referencing it goes out of scope.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: An iterator in C++? Explain the
open_questions.description: What is an iterator in C++? Explain the difference between begin() and end() iterators.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is an iterator in C++? Explain the difference between begin() and end() iterators.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: An iterator in C++ is an object that provides a way to access the elements of a container (like an array or a container from the Standard Library) in a sequential manner. begin() returns an iterator pointing to the first element of the container. end() returns an iterator pointing one past the last element of the container. It does not point to a valid element but is used to indicate the end of the sequence.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between const_iterator and iterator
open_questions.description: What is the difference between const_iterator and iterator in C++ when working with containers?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between const_iterator and iterator in C++ when working with containers?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: const_iterator is an iterator that points to constant elements within a container. It enforces that the elements it points to cannot be modified through the iterator. iterator is an iterator that can be used to modify elements within a container. It allows both reading and writing of elements.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The differences between std::thread and std::async
open_questions.description: Explain the differences between std::thread and std::async in C++ for achieving concurrency.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the differences between std::thread and std::async in C++ for achieving concurrency.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: std::thread is a low-level C++11 mechanism for creating and managing threads. It provides more control but requires explicit thread management, including joining or detaching threads. std::async is a higher-level C++11 feature that allows for the creation of asynchronous tasks. It returns a future representing the result, and the system decides whether to run the task asynchronously or synchronously. It provides a simpler interface for concurrency tasks.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of the explicit keyword
open_questions.description: What is the purpose of the explicit keyword in C++ constructors?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the purpose of the explicit keyword in C++ constructors?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The explicit keyword is used to prevent implicit type conversions during object initialization. When applied to a constructor, it requires that the constructor be called explicitly with the appropriate argument types, reducing the risk of unexpected conversions.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Multiple inheritance in C++, and how
open_questions.description: What is multiple inheritance in C++, and how is it different from single inheritance?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is multiple inheritance in C++, and how is it different from single inheritance?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Multiple inheritance in C++ allows a class to inherit from more than one base class. Single inheritance, on the other hand, allows a class to inherit from only one base class. Multiple inheritance can lead to the diamond problem and requires careful design.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice
